text: Hello and welcome, everyone.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is Physics as Information Processing, Session 4 on Communicating Observers.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's the 10th of August, 2023.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Chris, looking forward to this lecture.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Off to you.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Thank you, Daniel, and welcome to this session.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As Daniel said, this is about communicating observers and fasten your seatbelts because we have a lot to cover in the next hour.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So just to do a quick review, we've been talking about quantum information theory, and we've been talking about it in the simplest possible setting of two systems, Alice and Bob, that exchange information through their mutual boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we've assumed that everything is finite dimensional, so we don't need to worry about infinite energy transfer across this boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And of course, we assume conservation of energy, so there are no sources or sinks in either of the systems, Alice and Bob.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we emphasize that this way of depicting things is topological.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're not assuming any background geometry, no sort of spatial embedding, which is going to become very important in this session.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the last session, we talked about how the boundary, which I'll always call B,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It can be thought of as a channel that comprises n qubits that are independent.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And Alice and Bob each can prepare and measure those qubits.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they can always choose independently their reference frames for doing so.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So how they define up and down when they're measuring a spin with effectively a z-spin operator to interact with these qubits.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We talked a little bit about the free energy principle and its quantum formulation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the principle basically says that interacting systems will behave in a way that aligns their reference frames
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and that they therefore asymptotically approach entanglement.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the FEP is a classical limit of the principle of unitarity, and that's one reason for studying quantum information to learn more about the FEP, and so to learn more about active inference and what the theory of active inference says about agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And last time, we talked a lot about the constraints that are imposed by a limited free energy supply on any agent.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Recall that we talked about the fact that in the absence of sources of free energy within an agent,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So as long as you conserve energy globally, that the free energy that each agent uses has to come from its environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's clearly true for us.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have to consume oxygen and eat food and things like that to keep running as systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we discussed a little bit this theorem that if two reference frames or quantum processes, Q1 and Q2, don't commute, they have to be implemented by compartments that communicate classically.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we'll use this extensively today.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But the bottom line last time was that physics alone gives us compartmentalization in systems whenever the systems are complex enough to have multiple kinds of measurements that they can't deploy simultaneously.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So where we're going, today we're going to
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'll start from this place we left off last time of the possibility of agents that are compartmentalized and into compartments that have to communicate classically.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we're going to talk about agents that can be compartmentalized into multiple sub-agents that share an environment, the environment consisting of Bob, and how those agents talk about that shared environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the motivation for this is simple.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's that what we do all the time is a group activity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And what we're doing right now is a group activity that involves sharing an environment, what's shown on this screen, and talking about it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the whole post-session discussion process will be another example of just that sort of thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So to talk about science at all, or to talk about any kind of social relations, or to talk about anything other than solipsism, we have to be able to talk about how multiple agents communicate about some shared environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so that's what we're going to develop a formal way of talking about.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And there are two things to notice right off the top about this.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One is that the way we've defined interactions at boundaries, they're effectively instantaneous.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So each agent, remember,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: interacts with its boundary with some set of operators.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And what those operators do is effectively measure, each operator effectively measures the spin of a qubit.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this is a very fast process.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The other thing that we then need to notice is that if we have two agents and they're communicating with each other classically,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: then they're going to be using degrees of freedom of their shared environment in order to communicate.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's exactly what we're doing right now.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For example, we're using degrees of freedom of the internet to communicate.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm using degrees of freedom of the local atmosphere to talk to my microphone.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I'm using degrees of freedom of the local photon field to see my screen.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So all communication between agents, and certainly all classical communication between agents, uses degrees of freedom of the environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the environment, remember, is the other system, Bob, that's on the other side of that shared boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we're going to be interested in how components of ALICE use Bob as a communication channel, and in fact, as multiple communication channels.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I just wanted to quote my colleague and friend Mike Levin in his statement that all intelligence is composite.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: All of us, all organisms, even single cells, are composite systems that comprise many, many different agents that are able to make different kinds of measurements and execute different kinds of actions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and so have to communicate classically.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we're talking about all of life here as well as all of social systems and ecosystems and such things as that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the first thing I want to do today is simplify the notation so that we don't have to draw quite such complicated diagrams.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the picture on the left here is a picture from the last session.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It shows the structure of a very simple agent that makes some measurements using a reference frame called E and then writes some results of those measurements to memory using a reference frame called Y. And those two processes are connected by an internal clock.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that ticks between the input process and the output process.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the clock tick corresponds to the expenditure of free energy to write information irreversibly on the boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the memories are actually written on the boundary because that's where classical information lives in this theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you can think of this whole process from E through the clock and back to Y as a single quantum process or as a quantum computation that maps some sector E of the boundary to some sector Y of the boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so we can represent it in this much simpler way that's over on the right side as some process Q that maps some sector on the boundary to some other sector on the boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And formally, that process can be thought of as a topological quantum field theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Topological here is important.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's not geometric.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It doesn't assume an embedding in space, and this will become critically important later on.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the operation of that TQFT requires a clock tick, or it incorporates a tick of this internal clock.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we can do this because we were able to prove, Jim Glazeburg and Tonino Marciano and I were able to prove last year, that we can always represent a quantum reference frame as a topological quantum field theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this just illustrates the two kinds of transformations between quantum reference frames that are important.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can take one and divide it into two pieces that commute.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Or we can take a two-part reference frame and we can swap in another part
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that doesn't commute with the part that we've swapped it in for, but that does commute with the remainder of the reference frame.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So here R is the reference component of some object identification system, and we can swap in some different way of looking at the object once we've identified it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So for example, if the object that we're identifying
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: is a box that can measure both Z-spin and X-spin, then P and Q can be the Z-spin and X-spin settings on that box that allow us to effectively rotate the filter from this way to that way so that we measure vertical spin versus horizontal spin.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's really it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I mean, those are the ways that one can transform quantum reference frames.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Of course, we could do arbitrarily many compositions of this kind of transformation and do something very complicated, but they map very simply to TQFTs with the structure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you can construct categories out of this and find a functor that's well-defined that maps one category to another.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's an example of a nice use of categorical techniques for solving a problem that looks difficult, but in fact, it's very straightforward.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So using this simplified notation, it becomes very easy to see
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that if we have two systems, Alice and Bob, on opposite sides of this boundary, and we perfectly align their quantum reference frames, which is what the FEP says they will tend to do, then they become entangled.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you can see that they're entangled by seeing that once the reference frames are perfectly aligned,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: they jointly implement one quantum process.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And jointly implementing one quantum process just means you're entangled.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The two sides no longer have conditionally independent states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If one quantum process, which is time reversible, information preserving, is implemented jointly by the two systems,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So a lot of things like this become very simple when we think of these processes as just quantum computations going on inside some system, implemented by some system, and how those processes relate across some boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's what we're going to do for studying communication today.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Another thing to recall from a couple of sessions ago, or last session, is that if two reference frames, Q1 and Q2, commute, we can always join them together to form a single reference frame.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is just a graphical depiction in this simpler language of how that works.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: topologically there's no distinction between the left side and the right side what i've done is just squeeze the top two green circles together and the bottom two green circles together into one circle and that just makes a simple process connecting the top one to the bottom one so what we're going to be interested in is situations where this doesn't happen
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: where Alice consists of two components that execute reference frames that don't commute.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so the two components are conditionally independent.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They do each have free choice of reference frame.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so they have to communicate classically.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They don't share a single quantum process, so they're not entangled.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And before we go ahead to do that,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I just wanted to remind you of some of the no-go theorems that follow from this situation depicted on the right, where we have a single agent executing a single reference frame, a single process, a single kind of measurement, any set of commuting measurements that can be combined into one measurement.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And here are some things Alice can't do.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we've talked about some of these previously, so this is basically a reminder.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But Alice can't, using just one measurement, measure the entanglement entropy across her own boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So Alice can't know that she has an independent state.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: She can't know that she's not entangled with Bob.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's a useful thing to think about philosophically, as it applies to you and me.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can't actually know that we have independent states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Alice can't measure her own entanglement entropy, so she can't know whether she has components that have to communicate classically.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: She can't measure Bob's entanglement entropy,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So she can't know whether Bob has compartments that have to communicate classically.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if you think in terms of perception theory, this says Alice can't know whether Bob consists of separate objects that behave classically.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Their behavior can look classical to her, but she's not able to determine that their behavior is classical because she can't measure Bob's entanglement entropy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: She can't measure the dimension of her own boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And recall from a couple of times ago that the boundary includes some sector that supplies free energy that Alice can't extract information from for further processing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: She can only extract free energy from.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So she can't measure the dimension of that sector.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so she can't measure the dimension of the whole boundary itself.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this, of course, means that she can't measure her own dimension either.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And of course, she can't measure Bob's dimension because the only information she can get about Bob is the classical information that's encoded on this boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: She can't reach past the boundary to see how large a system Bob is.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's clearly connected to this first point that she can't measure the entanglement entropy across Bob, because the entanglement entropy can only be small if her dimension and Bob's dimension are both much larger than the dimension of the boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's a condition she can't check.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So all of these kind of no-go theorems lead off in interesting directions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the only one that we're really going to be interested in here
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: is the third one, the one about measuring Bob's entanglement entropy, because we want to talk specifically about how multiple agents, so multiple components of Alice, can access information about Bob's entanglement entropy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Okay, so recall from the end of the last session that the last thing we talked about was classical communication.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We talked about the fact that classical communication involves assumptions and pitfalls and that we have to be very careful whenever we talk about it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What we're going to do today is standard practice in physics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're simply going to stipulate that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: these components A1 and A2, the separable components of Alice, communicate classically.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so we're going to draw it like this.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're going to draw a classical channel between them.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that classical channel passes through Bob.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It uses degrees of freedom of the ambient photon field or the ambient atmosphere or pieces of paper or email or something like that that's out there in the environment to exchange classical messages.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And there are a couple of things to note here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I haven't even written down here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're assuming that A1 and A2 share some language for this classical communication.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's a big assumption, as we talked about last time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But I will note explicitly that classical communication takes time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's what defines classicality here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's causal, so it can't work faster than the speed of light.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is a topological theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We don't have an embedding geometry, so we can't at this point talk about light, which is a relationship between space and time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Because we've got time, we've got clocks, but we don't have any space.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But we can say that whatever passes through this classical channel requires at least one clock tick on Bob's side.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's a process that Bob has to execute.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and executing that process takes time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So getting the signal from me to you on the internet takes some time, so the environment's clock has to tick during that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And all of these assumptions bundled together turn out to be a fairly serious set of assumptions, and they involve assumptions about fine-tuning, about the universe being just right,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they should make us nervous.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I just want to leave it at that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We always assume with complete aplomb that agents can communicate classically, but it's not a straightforward assumption.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And it's worth, any of you who are looking for interesting research projects can look into the nature of classical communication.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's full of hidden assumptions and surprises and things that aren't at all straightforward, even though they look like they ought to be.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So there's a challenge.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So why do we assume this?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Why do we assume classical communication?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We do it because we have to if we're going to talk about detecting entanglement.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And most of you probably know the history of the notion of entanglement.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It was first noticed by Einstein, Podolsky, and Rosen, ever after called EPR.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: in 1935, and they wrote a paper which is infamous and called the EPR paper, in which they argued that the phenomenon of entanglement made no sense and couldn't possibly be physical.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Since quantum theory included this notion of entanglement, it couldn't possibly be a complete theory of what's going on in the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And Schrodinger replied the same year with a very detailed paper where he introduces, among other things, Schrodinger's cat as a paradox.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And he explains very clearly what entanglement is and why entanglement follows from quantum theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And he uses that discussion to argue that the classical notion of a physical state is not actually applicable to the world as it is.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So he answers the EPR paper very directly.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this discussion is currently mostly known as the Bohr-Einstein debate because, of course, Bohr already in 1928 had said in print that the classical notion of causality in space and time simply doesn't apply anymore.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And Einstein objected to that vigorously.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That was 1935, and it was almost 50 years later that entanglement was first observed in the laboratory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Here, the 1982 picture is a picture of the interior of Alan Aspat's laboratory when he performed the first entanglement experiment for which he finally won the Nobel Prize last year.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And these days, this kind of experiment is done all over the world and is even done with satellite-borne sources.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: ...resource is the key to quantum security, quantum security communication, as we'll discuss in quantum cryptography and quantum banking, the quantum internet, all this other stuff that you may have heard of.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So before talking more about these experiments, I just want to provide a definition of entanglement.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Entangled simply means not separable.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's the definition.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So a state, a joint state AB is entangled if and only if it does not factor.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: into two separable states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's the definition.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the literature, and especially the popular literature, is absolutely rife with hype and various kinds of mystification of entanglement and authors trying to convince you that entanglement is this amazing kind of woo-woo thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And whenever you run across that, go back to the definition.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I mean, entanglement simply means this simple mathematical condition of not separability or a state that isn't factorizable.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that means that the state does not display classical conditional independence.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So classically, that's the way to think about it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's a failure of conditional independence.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And it's ubiquitous in quantum theory, even though it wasn't actually observed for almost 50 years after it was predicted.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So here's what all these experiments look like.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're called Bell EPR experiments after John Bell.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: who derived the statistical criterion for detecting entanglement, and EPR, Einstein, Podolsky, and Rosen, who did this as a thought experiment and said, if this occurs in the theory, it can't possibly be real.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And of course it is real.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's now amply demonstrated by experimentation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Here's how they work.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's a source,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The source produces a state that is entangled.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I've written the typical, what's called a Bell state.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's up plus or minus down divided by the square root of two, just to normalize it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But up plus or minus down is clearly not the same as up times down.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this is not a separable state.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this state propagates outward in space and time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: to two observers who have independent laboratories, for example, on different continents in that space-based experiment that I showed you the picture of from the cover of Science a few years ago, 2017, I think.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The two observers have freedom to choose their own reference frame, their own z-axis for measuring spin.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They do a spin measurement, and they do this over and over and over again.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They accumulate statistics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they exchange their results so that they can analyze the joint statistics of their experiment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they check to see whether that joint statistics is consistent with classical probability theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if it isn't to a statistically significant level, then they've been able to detect entanglement.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, notice that this process requires classical communication.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They have to make their independent measurements in their own laboratories, and then they have to exchange results.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Or one of them has to send results to the other one, or they both have to send their results to some third party.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But in all of these cases, they're exchanging some classical data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so we have the assumption that whoever gets that classical data knows the language it was recorded in, and so can do a joint analysis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I'll just show you another picture of this experiment that's in a standard space-time diagram.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Here, time is vertical, space is horizontal.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The two observers are labeled Alice and Bob.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They share a quantum channel that goes from Alice to the source to Bob.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's the entangled state.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They do some processing and then one of them here, Bob, sends the results to Alice.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's a classical communication.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It takes time and it traverses space.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this step is classical.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this is why we have to assume classical communication to talk about detecting or using entanglement.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So now I want to represent this in a different way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: using our little picture earlier.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're going to think of Alice again as two components, A1 and A2.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're separable, so they have to communicate classically.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They have a classical channel that goes through Bob, and they also now share some quantum channel.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They share an entangled state.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the entangled state, of course, is produced by Bob.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The source is part of Bob.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And their detectors, if you want to think about it that way, are located on this boundary B, or their interface with the source is on this boundary B. And each of them executes a process that accumulates data from the quantum channel and communicates it to the other observer via the classical channel.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now this picture illustrates what's called a LOC protocol.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: LOC means local operations and classical communication.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So A1 and A2 are each operating locally on their boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're making measurements locally on their boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they're communicating via actions locally on their boundary and observations locally on their boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, for example, I'm communicating with my computer here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can consider it my boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And stuff is happening in the environment that's implemented by the internet.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you're receiving those communications locally on your boundary, on your laptop or whatever it is you're using.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's what local operations means.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And these protocols specifically involve classical communication, and so they're able to detect entanglement.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And a Bell EPR experiment is just an example of a lock protocol.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: the observers exchange information about how they're going to do their experiments.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're both going to measure z-spin.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're going to use independently chosen reference frames, and they're going to look at the output from some agreed-upon source.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's all classically set up.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Then they actually make their observations, and then they classically communicate their results.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So classical communication front and back.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Lock protocols are not limited to this sort of Bell EPR sort of setting.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can also represent a scattering experiment as a lock protocol.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So here's a representation of scattering as a lock protocol.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you can see all I've done is cut that previous boundary
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: at the division between A1 and A2, and I've then extended it in some external time, the time that is counted by Bob's clock, not by Alice's clock.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's what's meant by external time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I've relabeled Alice 2 as Alice 1 at a later time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So now what Alice is doing is communicating with her past self, or A1 is communicating with her future self.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they're each doing something different.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: A1 is executing a procedure that in the laboratory we call state preparation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: She's preparing a state that we'll call N, which is just the initial state of some scattering experiment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, for example, at the LHC, N is some state of two protons that are portaling around the ring at the LHC at close to the speed of light.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And Alice then later on at T plus delta T is doing a different kind of quantum process.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: She's analyzing the data coming out of something like the Atlas detector, which is a multi-particle counter that's located at the LHC.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they share a quantum channel, which is the scattering channel that takes the incoming state and produces the outgoing state.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I recall from the very first session, as Feynman told us, to understand this transition from in to out, we have to integrate over all possible paths that are consistent with conservation of space.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: spin-holicity, basically momentum plus spin.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: All the different spins that are relevant in a high-energy physics experiment, including things like lepton number, which is basically a spin.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, how do we know?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: How do we know what we have to conserve?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We know what we have to conserve because Alice is doing the experiment, has a classical memory
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that allows her to remember what she prepared.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: She can remember that what she did back in the past was set two protons counter-rotating in the LHC.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they had certain energies, and so they had certain momenta, and they were protons, so they had certain spin variables.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: All of that has to be remembered to make any sense of the output of the detectors.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and so to actually come up with a measured state that makes sense.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And very often this memory channel is neglected by physicists.

text: So does this imply that every time you have a log channel, the quantum part is like a scattering picture, like a unitary evolution, even in the earlier EPR picture?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Is that quantum channel portion always a unitary evolution scattering picture?

text: Thank you.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Yes, for essentially the reason that...
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To find the classical channel, you're always assuming you have something that's protected from decoherence by the environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, yeah, if you're doing an EPR experiment, you have to assume that you don't have an environmental decoherence between the source and the detectors.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And similarly, when you're doing a scattering experiment, you have to make the assumption that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: the environment is not reaching in there and messing with the outgoing state that you're going to see or reaching in and messing with the incoming state and changing it in some way that re-prepares it in a way that you don't know, that you have no knowledge of.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So yes, you're making a fairly strong anti-decoherence assumption in any of these settings when you're talking about having a quantum channel.

text: Does that answer the question?

text: Yes, thank you.

text: Okay, great.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we can think of Locke, we can think of scattering as Locke.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I just wanted to now emphasize that effectively what Locke is implementing is two parallel memories, a classical memory
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: which, as we said in the case of scattering, is memory for preparation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the PR case, it's memory for preparation, for what the experimental setup is, for what the instructions for doing the experiment are.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we also have a quantum channel, which is effectively another memory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's something that's extended through time,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And again, it's implemented by the environment, implemented by Bob, and it involves Bob's clock ticking.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So whenever we have two memories in parallel, we can construct an error-correcting code.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So think of a simple classical error-correcting code.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For example, the use of parity bits
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: in exchanging digital data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if I send you a bit string, classically, and I send it to you two or three times, so there's some redundancy in my signal, and I send you a parity bit, I say, okay, add up your bit string and the result should be one.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's one on my side.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If you add it up and you get zero, there's an error someplace.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: you can use that parity bit to detect errors.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you can throw out the bit strings that you receive that have parity zero and say, oh, the environment interfered somehow with the signal or some eavesdropper interfered with the signal and made a mistake or something like that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this corresponds to environmental decoherence not being a good assumption, even though it's classical.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Environmental interference is not a good assumption in this case.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So a quantum error correct encode is basically the same idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I use some feature of the fact that I have two different memories and that I'm encoding something in time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm encoding multiple replicates of something in time to provide a way of checking to make sure that I'm sending the correct message.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I can, for example, consider the message to be my classical memory and consider the quantum process as a process that tests that memory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I remember that I need to do experiment X and I will get result Y. I actually do experiment X on this quantum channel and see if I get result Y.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and if I don't get a result Y, then something's wrong.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Either I can't trust the quantum channel, or I've remembered my preparation conditions incorrectly.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I'm using one memory to check the accuracy of the other.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this problem
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: using something about the environment, some channel in the environment, to check memory is absolutely ubiquitous.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we use it all the time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, for example, look around your room, and your room hopefully looks more or less the same now that it did at the start of this session.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's very reassuring.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It reassures you that something's not happening in the environment that's dangerous and disturbing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if you couldn't do that, if your environment was constantly changing and there was no familiarity about the environment, you wouldn't be able to check your memory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You wouldn't be able to check your sanity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So even though we don't think about
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: our local environments as effectively an error correcting code.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's exactly how we use it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We use Stigmergic memory or memory out there in the environment as a way of checking our own memories and assuring that our memory is OK.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I talked a little bit about quantum security.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Here's how quantum security system works.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Again, it's a lock protocol.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have some classical signal that can be thought of as a code or a key or a one-time pad, for example, that encodes a way of doing experiments.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And once that's been exchanged, assuming it's secure, then we can use the quantum channel to communicate information.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the classical channel has told us what we have to do with that quantum channel.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have to make certain kinds of measurements at, say, particular clock times as measured, and we'll get information sent from the past, from the sender.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The classical channel protects the quantum channel from adversarial agents because anything that an adversarial agent does to the quantum channel, if some agent tries to eavesdrop, for example, on the quantum channel, they'll disrupt the quantum channel and the results of our measurement
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: will not be what's expected given the protocol that we have run.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So quantum communication is secured by the fact that interfering with some entangled state actually destroys the state, so it's detectable.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can always know if someone is trying to disrupt our communications, which isn't true if we just have two classical channels.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Charlie can always intercept a message and then recreate it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's not possible with a quantum channel.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So let's refold this diagram so that we've taken the external time back out of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we have this picture where the two components of Alice are just interacting via their shared boundary with their environment, Bob.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And now we can see that the source of redundancy is not time, it's the boundary itself.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Just sharing the boundary allows Alice's components, A1 and A2, to put copies of the same information on different places on the boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the boundary now becomes a resource for redundant storage of information.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So Alice 1 and Alice 2 can use different parts of the boundary to check what other parts of the boundary say, to check the information that's encoded on other parts of the boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they can define an error-correcting code on the boundary itself using this lock protocol.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I just want to leave you with this idea that using classical and quantum channels together allows us to define error-correcting codes on boundaries that we share as separate agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And leave you to think about
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What shared measurements, what shared quantum reference frames, let us as agents see the same things?
